newsitem.title: USA: Nu-Kote's, Epson's legal battle continues. [CORRECTED 19:24 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Nu-Kote's, Epson's legal battle continues. [CORRECTED 19:24 GMT]

text.p: The legal battle between Epson America Inc and Nu-Kote Holdings over the latter's ink jet cartridges took a new twist Friday, as a federal judge held Nu-Kote in contempt and ordered it to recall its cartridges, but at the same time stayed his decision.

Epson said the U.S. District Court in Los Angeles Thursday held Nu-Kote Holdings Inc in contempt for selling cartridges for Epson ink jet printers in violation of an 1995 injunction and ordered a recall of all cartridges sold by Nu-Kote that violate Epson's 401 utility patent.
The judge, however, stayed both the recall and sanction payments pending an expected appeal to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
Epson, an affiliate of Seiko Corp, said the ruling applies to cartridges sold by Nu-Kote from March 10 through August 6.
No-Kote's outside counsel (corrects from general counsel) Ronald Katz said in an interview the ruling was "actually better than we expected."

"With respect to anything that's on the shelves right now, that will be sold before the stay is lifted," Katz said, adding "it's probably going to take a year" for the appelate court to review the case."
The judge's order followed an August 11 ruling that required Nu-Kote to pay Epson $1 million for selling cartridges before March 10 in violation of the injunction.

Nu-Kote's Katz said Thursday in an interview that Nu-Kote redesigned its Epson-compatible cartridges to avoid the injunction. A Nu-Kote spokesman added Friday the company has offered to exchange all its older cartridges with the newly designed ones.

But Epson's assistant general counsel (corrects from general counsel) Alf Andersen said Thursday in an interview Epson believes its 401 patent covers all Epson-compatible cartridges made by Nu-Kote, including the newly-designed ones.

The August 11 ruling specifically named Nu-Kote's RF60, RF61 and RF62 cartridges in violation of Epson's patent. A Nu-Kote spokesman said the company no longer ships these cartridges but added retailers may still sell the RF60 and RF62.
Epson's Andersen said the company will probably file a motion asking the court to specifically order an injunction against Nu-Kote's newly designed cartridges for violating Epson's patent.
